block.p: Zimbabwe Opposition Gains In Parliamentary Elections Results from weekend voting showed the fledgling opposition party making unprecedented gains on the party that has dominated Zimbabwe for 20 years. But the governing party was expected to hold its majority, once the count was completed.

I.R.A. Arms Caches Inspected Two international envoys, one from Finland and the other from Africa, inspected a number of the guerrillas' secret arms dumps, a significant step in advancing the Northern Ireland peace settlement. The inspections fulfilled a promise made by the I.R.A. in May in response to demands that it move toward dismantling its arsenal in exchange for Britain's restoring the authority of the new Catholic-Protestant power-sharing Northern Ireland government.

Text of Third Secret of Fatima The Vatican issued a photocopy of the manuscript of the long undisclosed prophecy that has fascinated Fatima conspiracy theorists for decades. The Vatican revealed its interpretation last month, that the prophecy referred to the 1981 assassination attempt on Pope John Paul II, but controversy continued.

Allies Were Told of Nazi Plans British and American intelligence agents had information in 1943 that could have helped save Italian Jews from a death camp, historians said, citing declassified documents. The historians said Western officials might have been able to warn Jews in Rome about Nazi plans.

Kremlin Reversal on Chechnya The Kremlin said the attacks on Chechnya would continue, one day after a top commander announced a halt to artillery and air strikes in the breakaway province. The reversal raised new questions about the military's pronouncements and was a setback for a government effort to promote understanding of its military campaign in the West.

Caution at Democracy Meeting The French foreign minister dampened the celebratory tone of a conference on democracy in Poland, saying that imposing democracy on a country could have the opposite result. An American official responded that the purpose of the meeting was to have countries that chose democracy help one another.

A List of Tax Shelters The 29-member Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development issued a list of 35 places, mostly exotic island getaways, that have tax laws intended to attract assets from companies and people who want to evade tax payments or potential tax liabilities in their home countries. The organization identified 47 other places with laws it found potentially harmful.

World Bank Self-Criticism An internal inquiry delivered a scathing assessment that the World Bank violated its own rules when it rushed to approve a Chinese poverty-reduction plan that involved relocating 58,000 poor farmers on the edge of Tibet. The project raised a storm of protest.

Court Upholds Miranda Rule As Part of the 'Culture' The Supreme Court, voting 7 to 2, reaffirmed the Miranda decision on the required police warnings to suspects about their rights. In an opinion by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, the court said that because the 1966 Miranda decision had ''announced a constitutional rule'' a statute by which Congress sought to overrule it was itself unconstitutional.

The court declared New Jersey's hate crime law unconstitutional, on the twin grounds that it improperly permitted the judge, rather than the jury, to make the crucial finding that the crime was motivated by bias, and that it did not require proof of that beyond a reasonable doubt.
New Jersey officials said they would bring the law into compliance.
The Supreme Court invalidated California's blanket primary, saying it stripped political parties of the ability to control their own nominating process and define their identity.
U.S. Surplus Projection Rises President Clinton raised his projection of the budget surplus by nearly $1.3 trillion for the next decade.

House Vote on Gun Safety Deal The House, voting 201 to 196, rejected an effort that would have prevented the Justice Department from spending any money to enact or enforce an agreement between the Clinton administration and Smith & Wesson on marketing and safety measures.

Bush Would Split I.N.S. Gov. George W. Bush proposed the splitting of the Immigration and Naturalization Service into two separate agencies, one to deal with law enforcement and the other to provide services to immigrants. In a separate speech at a C.O.R.E. gathering in Manhattan, he called for financing mentoring programs for children whose parents are in prison.

Last Try by Elian Relatives The Miami relatives of Elian Gonzalez asked the Supreme Court to block the boy's return to Cuba, pending a formal appeal. If the court denies the request or declines to take up the issue, Elian will be free to return to Cuba after 4 p.m. tomorrow.

Drug Price Rise Hits Elderly Spending on prescription drugs increased a record 17.4 percent last year, and elderly people experienced the largest cost increases, a study by a drug benefits company said.

Police Discipline Officer They Say Ignored Complaint A 10-year veteran of the police force, Officer Donna Gaudino, 40, was suspended for what officials said was her failure to aid a teenager who said he was sexually abused in Greenwich Village after the annual Gay and Lesbian Pride March on Sunday.

Power Cuts on East Side Problems with feeder cables led Con Edison to reduce power by 8 percent to an Upper East Side area with 76,000 customers. Power was cut off to six buildings, and two hospitals and the Metropolitan Museum of Art were asked to switch to their own generators. Power usage in the city for the day was the third highest on record, the utility said. Power was restored by 11 p.m.

Study on Welfare Reduction A study financed by the United Way and focused on an Upper Manhattan welfare office found that of 174 families who reported having problems with welfare benefits, 93 percent had either been wrongly denied benefits or had wrongly had them cut off.

The Human Blueprint Two rival groups of scientists said in a joint announcement that they had deciphered the set of genetic instructions that defines the human organism. Understanding the human genome is expected to revolutionize the practice of medicine.

Ebola Without the Symptoms The Ebola virus, which has caused deaths from high fever and bleeding in African outbreaks, can also infect without producing illness, African and European scientists reported.
Yanks Switch Focus to Sosa The Yankees ended an effort to acquire the slugger Juan Gonzalez from Detroit but were said to have stepped up their effort to get Sammy Sosa from the Chicago Cubs.
Nets Said to Settle on Coach The Nets are expected to announce that their new coach will be Byron Scott, an assistant coach with the Sacramento Kings.
No Rate Rise Foreseen Economists and analysts, saying the economy is showing enough signs of slowing, expect the Fed to leave interest rate policy unchanged when it meets today and tomorrow.

Money Store to Be Shut Down First Union said it would close the Money Store, a second-mortgage lender promoted by the retired athletes Phil Rizzuto and Jim Palmer. It also said it would get out of or scale back other businesses.

European Hurdle to Phone Deal The top antitrust officer of the European Commission said he would seek to block WorldCom from buying Sprint unless the companies significantly altered terms of the deal.
New President of ABC TV ABC named Alex Wallau, one of its longest-serving executives and the network's boxing analyst, president of the ABC Television Network.
Lucien Laurin The trainer of Secretariat, the 1973 Triple Crown winner who was perhaps the fastest thoroughbred that ever raced, was 88.
